snippet: The social media company gave the messages to a judge but is appealing their provision to prosecutors; the case may have wide effects on law enforcement’s access to material placed on the Internet.
abstract: Twitter submits messages, written by Occupy Wall Street protester Malcolm Harris during a protest on the Brooklyn Bridge, to Judge Matthew A Sciarrino Jr of Criminal Court in Manhattan in response to subpeona; Harris, arrested along with about 700 other protesters after they walked in the bridge's roadway, has argued that they were purposely led off the pedestrian path by police; case has broader significance for the effect it may have on how much access law enforcement has to material published on social media Web sites.
lead_paragraph: The social media company gave the messages to a judge but is appealing their provision to prosecutors; the case may have wide effects on law enforcement’s access to material placed on the Internet.

headline.seo: Twitter Turns Over Messages in Occupy Protest Case
headline.main: Twitter Turns Over User’s Messages in Occupy Wall Street Protest Case
headline.print_headline: Twitter Turns Over User’s Messages In Occupy Wall Street Protest Case
